text: the larger the IceCube less the surface
area exposed to the drink the less its
gonna melt I'm Kristin Willy from
Brooklyn's Long Island Bar here with
bone Appetit in the Test Kitchen to talk
to you about ice they often forgot that
critical component to your cocktail ice
is one of the things I get the most
questions about because it can look so
professional in the bar and so amateur
at home this is a tempered piece of ice
it's been sitting out for about 30
minutes you can see right through it and
you know it's ready to go because
there's no matte finish around the
outside of it to get going I'm gonna
score the top of the ice about two
inches in it doesn't have to be a major
groove just really a guide for the knife
and then we're gonna flip it over and
score the bottom I'm gonna take my
muddler which I use for cocktails and
gently tap the back of the knife then
you end up with a column from here it's
much easier to break it down this is
your traditional size of an ice cube for
a cocktail bar they're gonna be a little
irregular but we can revisit that with a
paring knife or the ice pick to shape it
how we need to if you don't happen to
have a giant slab of ice at home coming
out of your freezer the Tove lo mold is
a great way to make the same ice cubes
now they can get really cloudy if you
quickly freeze them with your generic
cold water so you fill it up with hot
water the warm water has less suspended
air in it creating less of that
cloudiness later when they're done
freezing my favorite way to use this
giant cube it's just a poor little neat
whiskey over the top of it prefer some
bourbon usually about two ounces right
over the cube and that's gonna sit there
for a very long time without getting too
watery of having a big cube within the
whiskey like this is great because it
actually can open up the whiskey a ton
and it happens it's such a slow rate
with these low surface area that you get
to explore all the different flavors
it's gonna start out strong but then
open up at the water that's melting into
it and get even better over time Cheers
